thread.title: El Hadji Diouf to go into POLITICS as Liverpool flop eyes Senegalese parliament
thread.title_full: El Hadji Diouf to go into POLITICS as Liverpool flop eyes Senegalese parliament

author: tsheen
title: El Hadji Diouf to go into POLITICS as Liverpool flop eyes Senegalese parliament
text:
El Hadji Diouf to go into POLITICS as Liverpool flop eyes Senegalese parliament 
Controversial forward says he has a 'passion' to help the people of his nation By STEVE GOODMAN Comments EL Hadji Diouf has threatened to wreak havoc in his home country … by going into POLITICS. 
The controversial ex-Liverpool flop, 36, figured in a series of spitting incidents and bust-ups throughout his stormy career. Getty Images 3 Diouf was a controversial, divisive figure during his time in Britain 
Diouf, who retired in 2015, now plans to turn his back on management in favour of becoming an MP in his native Senegal. 
He said: “My future is defined. In the next two years I will be joining politics, because I know from that point I can change a lot in football. 
“I have a lot of passion for politics, and I have people in Senegal who are mentoring me. That is the future for me, because a lot of Senegalese people are able to listen to me. 
“I took high-level coaching courses, but decided not to continue since I have better plans on things I want to do. 
“But I am always available to advise my team [Senegal] whenever called upon.” Getty Images Diouf caused controversy after spitting at a fan at the end of a Uefa Cup tie with Celtic RELATED STORIES El-Hadji Diouf slams Liverpool legend Steven Gerrard by saying former team-mate was 'nothing' Jealous Steve Mario Balotelli failed as Liverpool striker because of club legend Steven Gerrard, says former Reds striker El-Hadji Diouf LALLA LAND Adam Lallana scoffs EIGHT meals a day in crazy diet designed to keep up energy levels... after taking cookery lessons with Jurgen Klopp's chef Ponts in the bag Blackburn 1 Leeds 2: Pontus Jansson's dramatic late header keeps pressure on promotion rivals ANOTHER CLOUGH NO-GO Bolton turn down staggering £2m bid from Nottingham Forest for young striker Zach Clough Bore draw Sunderland 0 Tottenham 0: Frustration for Mauricio Pochettino as Spurs drop crucial points in the title race as Black Cats move then off the bottom Red mist Motherwell vs Rangers: Forward Michael O’Halloran and Scott McDonald both send off in high tempered clash 
A £10million Liverpool buy from French club Lens in 2002, Diouf went on to play for Bolton, Sunderland, Blackburn, Rangers, Doncaster and Leeds before ending his career with Malaysian club Sabah. 
Twice named African Footballer of the Year, he shone at the 2002 World Cup, and won 69 caps for the Teranga Lions. Liverpool 1-1 Chelsea : Simon Mignolet goes from zero to hero by denying late Diego Costa penalty
